s.text: Robert Wise's 1963 original, based on Shirley Jackson's The Haunting of Hill House , is overrated, but it manages to evoke the eeriest aspect of Jackson's fiction: the way the characters' neuroses acquire an inexorable life of their own and threaten to eat them alive.
Thanks to first-rate sound equipment, though, we hear everything they hear--especially a snapping of branches in the dark outside their tent that escalates into an omnidirectional clatter.
Thanks to first-rate sound equipment, though, we hear everything they hear--especially a snapping of branches in the dark outside their tent that escalates into an omnidirectional clatter.
Here are sound effects so hammy that they might have been borrowed from one of those old haunted-house party albums.
Thanks to first-rate sound equipment, though, we hear everything they hear--especially a snapping of branches in the dark outside their tent that escalates into an omnidirectional clatter.
The grueling monotony is broken only at night, when the students go into their tents and the sounds come again and the very celluloid seems to shiver with cold and fear.
Thanks to first-rate sound equipment, though, we hear everything they hear--especially a snapping of branches in the dark outside their tent that escalates into an omnidirectional clatter.

In the new version, directed by Jan De Bont ( Speed , 1994; Twister , 1996), that pounding comes early and serves as an overture for a bunch of computer-generated special effects: ghosties that swirl around like Tinkerbell, statues that spring to life and grab people.

' " The other day an envelope arrived at my door with a bunch of sticks lashed together in the familiar form of the Blair Witch talisman.
' " The other day an envelope arrived at my door with a bunch of sticks lashed together in the familiar form of the Blair Witch talisman.
With all those cameras onscreen, they've liberated horror from the realm of movies--from the realm of the light--and nestled it back into the dark where it was born.
The action unfolds in a season halfway between autumn and winter, and the washed-out tones suggest that the Blair Witch took the forest's colors with her when she died.
They have reanimated the genre not by adding to it but subtracting from it--by cooking it down to its bare bones and then rattling those bones like fiends.
